<misra_rule>

<instruction>

They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.

<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of consumer_thread:
```c
static void *consumer_thread(void *arg)
{
	(void)arg;
	metal_mutex_acquire(&lock);
	while (!counter)
		metal_condition_wait(&nempty_condv, &lock);
	counter--;
	metal_condition_signal(&nfull_condv);
	metal_mutex_release(&lock);

	return NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function consumer_thread:
METAL_MUTEX_DEFINE(lock)
...
static struct metal_condition nempty_condv = METAL_CONDITION_INIT
...
static struct metal_condition nfull_condv = METAL_CONDITION_INIT
...
static unsigned int counter
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No explicit compiler language extensions are present in the provided code fragment. The function signature (static void *consumer_thread(void *arg)), the cast-to-void to suppress unused-parameter warnings ((void)arg;), the while (!counter) loop, calls to metal_* functions, the METAL_MUTEX_DEFINE/ METAL_CONDITION_INIT identifiers and the return NULL; statement are all valid standard C constructs and do not by themselves constitute use of a compiler extension. 

Note: The macros METAL_MUTEX_DEFINE and METAL_CONDITION_INIT (and any underlying definitions of metal_mutex_acquire/metal_condition_wait/etc.) are not expanded in the supplied code. If those macro or function definitions use compiler-specific extensions (for example, __attribute__, __asm__, typeof, __extension__, or other tokens documented as compiler extensions), those expansions would need to be inspected to detect Rule 1.2 violations. Based solely on the visible code, there are no language extensions to report.
